title: Pro Tips For Cutting Your Nails

steps.title: Soften your nails first by soaking them in water or showering.
steps.content: Soften your nails first by soaking them in water or showering. Softening your nails will make them easier to trim and less likely to split. After soaking or showering, dry off your nails. [1] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source This step is especially important for toenails. Toenails tend to be thicker and tougher than fingernails, especially on your big toe.

steps.title: Make small cuts straight across your nail.
steps.content: Make small cuts straight across your nail. Cut your nails using a series of small cuts rather than one large cut. As Nagorska explains, cutting the entire nail in one go will “unnecessarily bend and weaken your nail at the sides. Instead, clip the nail a few times, starting at one side, going across the nail to the other side.” [2] X Expert Source Marta Nagorska Nail Artist Expert Interview. 26 May 2021. Round out the nail at the edge with a small cut. This helps the nail stay strong and reduces the chance of developing ingrown nails . [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Be careful not to cut too much. It can be tempting to keep trimming your nails, but if you trim too deeply, you can expose the sensitive skin beneath the nail and increase the risk of infection. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: File your nails after you cut them.
steps.content: File your nails after you cut them. Nagorska advises using a nail file to shape your nails and make sure the edges of the nail are smooth. [5] X Expert Source Marta Nagorska Nail Artist Expert Interview. 26 May 2021. Always file gently, in one long stroke, from the side to the center of the nail. Use the coarse, shaping side first if you need to remove more nail. Then, use the finer-grade shaping side to smooth your nails out. [6] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source You don’t have to file your nails, but the process can help shape your nails exactly as you want them. Jagged nails can catch on clothes, socks, and pantyhose. If your nails catch on something, they may tear or break. Aim to make your nails slightly triangular or ovular but never pointed. This helps keep them from breaking. Nails can weaken if you file too deeply into the corners and sides. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Moisturize your nails.
steps.content: Moisturize your nails. When you’re done trimming your nails, moisturize your nails and skin with a lotion of your choice. This helps bring moisture back into your nails, preventing splits and breakage. [8] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Look for lotions with hydrating ingredients like ceramides and hyaluronic acid, as these will help replenish your skin best. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Trim your nails once a week.
steps.content: Trim your nails once a week. Nails grow about 1 ⁄ 10 inch (2.5 mm) every month, meaning that it takes 3 to 6 months to grow a full nail. [10] X Research source If you cut your nails frequently—say, once each week or two—you won't need to worry about them growing too long or too wild. If your nails begin to hurt at the edges, you might be developing an ingrown nail ; try to trim away the painful growth before it goes too deep, but it would be wiser to seek a health care professional.

steps.title: Leave your cuticles alone.
steps.content: Leave your cuticles alone. It may be tempting to pick at or trim your cuticles when you’re cutting your nails, but do your best to leave them be. Cuticles protect your nail root, and cutting or pushing them back too aggressively could damage your nail or lead to an infection. [11] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Care for your cuticles by moisturizing regularly or using a cuticle oil to soften them before a manicure or pedicure.

steps.title: Choose the cutting tool that’s best for you.
steps.content: Choose the cutting tool that’s best for you. You can use nail clippers or manicure scissors to trim your nails. The choice is largely a matter of preference. Consider the pros and cons of each option: [12] X Research source Nail clippers are cheap, simple, and widely available. They cut your nails along a set concave edge—which can be very convenient if the clippers fit your nails, but frustrating if the crescent is too large or too small. Toenail clippers usually feature a heavier bite and a straighter edge to contend with thicker nails and the risk of ingrown toenails. Manicure scissors are less common than nail clippers, but some people greatly prefer them. You may need somewhat more finesse to trim your nails with manicure scissors. However, you also have more control over the arc of the cut. Avoid using any other sharp-cutting tools—such as knives, razor blades, or regular scissors—to trim your nails. The tool may slip and injure the skin surrounding the nail.

steps.title: Clean your nails when you wash your hands.
steps.content: Clean your nails when you wash your hands. Regularly cleaning under your fingernails and toenails helps you stay healthy. Bacteria can grow under your nails, resulting in infections and split nails. To prevent this, wash and scrub under your nails every time you wash your hands or bathe. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Nagorska recommends using a manicure brush to clean under your nails. Similarly, you can also use a wet wipe wrapped around a manicure stick or eyelash spoolie. [14] X Expert Source Marta Nagorska Nail Artist Expert Interview. 26 May 2021.

steps.title: Remember to clean your clippers after each use.
steps.content: Remember to clean your clippers after each use. If possible, buy your own set of nail-cutting tools and keep separate sets for your fingernails and toenails. Wash the implements regularly with a disinfectant to prevent infection. Dish detergent or antibacterial soap will do: just soak the cutting tools for 10 minutes in a bowl full of hot water and some soap. [15] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Be mindful of where you cut your nails.
steps.content: Be mindful of where you cut your nails. Make sure that you set up a place for your nail clippings to go. Consider clipping your nails into a trashcan or compost bin. Hold your fingers and toes directly over the receptacle, and try to track down the clippings that fly astray. Try not to clip your nails in public spaces. You can compost fingernails and toenails. They won't add much bulk to the pile, but they are organic matter and will decompose. Don't try to compost fake nails (acrylics) or excessively polished nails, as these artificial materials will not degrade.

steps.title: Why is it important to cut your fingernails?
steps.content: Why is it important to cut your fingernails? It’s important to cut your nails to prevent bacteria growth. Having good hand (and foot) hygiene is crucial to staying healthy. Cleaning and trimming your fingernails regularly helps you stay healthy. [16] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Should nails be cut straight or curved?
steps.content: Should nails be cut straight or curved? Nails should be cut straight when trimming. If you trim your nails at an angle, it could result in painful hangnails. Cut your nails straight across, then use a file to shape them as you like. [17] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Is it better to cut fingernails wet or dry?
steps.content: Is it better to cut fingernails wet or dry? Whether nails should be cut wet or dry is a controversial debate. Some believe they’re easier to cut when wet and prevent breakage and tearing, while others believe the opposite. All in all, health professionals recommend soaking your nails or taking a shower or bath before cutting them. [18] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source
